answer:
**Frame-by-Frame Analysis**  
• **Frame 1 and Frame 2:** The view is looking downhill at an intersection. Although it is dark, there do not appear to be any cars stopped directly in front of the ego vehicle. There also is no indication of rain on the windshield or roadway.  
• **Frame 3:** Beginning to see “STOP” road markings painted on the pavement in the lane ahead (the word “TOP” is visible just behind the crosswalk stripes). A red, octagonal sign is faintly visible on the right side of the intersection in the distance.  
• **Frame 4:** The painted “STOP” on the roadway is more complete. The red stop sign on the right is now very clear. No evidence suggests the traffic light in the far distance is red (we see that cross‐traffic lights are green).  
• **Frame 5:** The intersection’s stop sign is fully in view on the right, and the word “STOP” across the lane is easy to read. No car is blocking the lane, and there is no sign of rain.  

**Contextual Reasoning**  
The progressive emergence of a “STOP” sign and corresponding pavement markings across these frames strongly indicates the driver must legally stop at this intersection. There is no red traffic signal; indeed, the traffic lights farther ahead are green. Nor is there a stationary vehicle blocking the lane or heavy rain visible in any frame.

**Match to Answer Choices**  
• A: All‐way stop sign → Consistent with the visible red STOP sign and the road markings.  
• B: Red light → The traffic lights in the distance are green, so this is not correct.  
• C: Stopped car → There is no vehicle stopped in ego’s lane forcing the slowdown.  
• D: Heavy rain → Road and windshield appear dry.

**Provide the Best Answer**  
Stopping is required at the clearly marked stop sign, which is why ego is slowing down.  

<answer>A. All-way stop sign.</answer>
